**G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to **G.L. c. 212, § 4** because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000 and the cause of action arises within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

**G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1**.proposition: Venue is proper in **Suffolk County** under **G.L. c. 223, § 1** because the tort occurred in Boston, Suffolk County.

**G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14**.proposition: Defendant’s conduct violated **G.L. c. 90, § 14** and constituted negligence per se under Massachusetts law.

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B**.proposition: Award **pre‑ and post‑judgment interest** pursuant to **G.L. c. 231, § 6B**;

*Carter v. Yardley & Co.*, 319 Mass. 92.proposition: See **G.L. c. 90, § 14**, requiring motorists to ensure it is safe before opening any vehicle door on a public way; see also *Carter v. Yardley & Co.*, 319 Mass. 92 (1946) (defining negligence as the failure to exercise the care of a reasonably prudent person under the circumstances).
*Carter v. Yardley & Co.*, 319 Mass. 92.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss negligence generally, but it does not provide a concise, general definitional statement that ‘negligence is the failure to exercise the care of a reasonably prudent person under the circumstances.’ Instead, it develops duty and foreseeability principles in the products‑liability context and focuses on manufacturer liability to remote vendees. The case says nothing about G.L. c. 90, § 14 or door‑opening duties of motorists, and it is not an apt authority for that statutory proposition. Using Carter as the cited definitional source for the quoted negligence standard is therefore inaccurate.
*Carter v. Yardley & Co.*, 319 Mass. 92.relevant_excerpt: “In principle, a manufacturer or other person owning or controlling a thing that is dangerous in its nature or is in a dangerous condition, either to his knowledge or as a result of his want of reasonable care in manufacture or inspection, who deals with or disposes of that thing in a way that he foresees or in the exercise of reasonable care ought to foresee will probably carry that thing into contact with some person, known or unknown, who will probably be ignorant of the danger, owes a legal duty to every such person to use reasonable care to prevent injury to him.”

*Vega v. Walsh*, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 1034.proposition: See *Vega v. Walsh*, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 1034 (1989); *Glanz v. Gabor*, 374 Mass. 814 (1978); *Poirier v. Plymouth*, 374 Mass. 206 (1978).

*Glanz v. Gabor*, 374 Mass. 814 (1978).proposition: See *Vega v. Walsh*, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 1034 (1989); *Glanz v. Gabor*, 374 Mass. 814 (1978); *Poirier v. Plymouth*, 374 Mass. 206 (1978).
*Glanz v. Gabor*, 374 Mass. 814 (1978).case_name: Hastings & Sons Publishing v. City Treasurer of Lynn
*Glanz v. Gabor*, 374 Mass. 814 (1978).support_reasoning: The claimed proposition is only a string citation to three cases without stating any legal principle, so it is impossible to determine precisely what rule of law is being attributed to Glanz v. Gabor. Glanz itself squarely holds that municipal payroll records, including police off-duty detail payments, are public records subject to disclosure under G.L. c. 66, § 10 and not exempt under the privacy exemption. Without knowing the specific proposition from Vega v. Walsh for which Glanz is being cited, I cannot reliably say the case supports it.
*Glanz v. Gabor*, 374 Mass. 814 (1978).relevant_excerpt: We affirm the order and the judgment on the ground that payroll records of municipal employees, including records of disbursements to police for off-duty work details, are subject to disclosure under G. L. c. 66, § 10. ... We agree with the judge’s ruling that there was no showing that disclosure of payroll records would constitute an invasion of personal privacy. ... The names and salaries of municipal employees, including disbursements to policemen for off-duty work details, are not the kind of private facts that the Legislature intended to exempt from mandatory disclosure.

*Poirier v. Plymouth*, 374 Mass. 206 (19.proposition: See *Vega v. Walsh*, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 1034 (1989); *Glanz v. Gabor*, 374 Mass. 814 (1978); *Poirier v. Plymouth*, 374 Mass. 206 (1978).
*Poirier v. Plymouth*, 374 Mass. 206 (19.support_reasoning: The quoted passage is only Justice Quirico’s concurrence, not the majority opinion, and it mainly objects to the majority’s decision to abrogate the ‘hidden defect’ rule in this case. The proposition cited (along with Vega and Glanz) likely concerns the substantive change or application of premises-liability standards, which would come from the majority opinion, not this concurrence. Based solely on the provided text, we cannot confirm that this excerpt affirmatively supports the proposition; it in fact questions whether this is the proper case to abrogate the hidden-defect rule.
*Poirier v. Plymouth*, 374 Mass. 206 (19.relevant_excerpt: "However, the court has chosen to go beyond that and has declared, for the reasons discussed in part 4 of the opinion, that the 'hidden defect' rule 'no longer is to be applied in cases involving tort actions against landowners.' ... However, for all of the reasons stated above it is my opinion that this is not the appropriate case in which to abrogate the rule."

*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.raw_text: *Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.*, 408 Mass. 355, 358 (1990)
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.proposition: See *Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.*, 408 Mass. 355, 358 (1990) (violation of statutory duty is evidence of negligence); *Lyon v. Morphew*, 424 Mass. 828 (1997).
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the effect of violating G.L. c. 138, § 69 and reiterates Massachusetts’ rule that such a statutory violation is not negligence per se but is only “some evidence” of negligence. That directly matches the proposition that violation of a statutory duty is evidence of negligence (rather than conclusively establishing negligence).
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. … Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).”

*Lyon v. Morphew*, 424 Mass. 828 (1997).proposition: See *Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.*, 408 Mass. 355, 358 (1990) (violation of statutory duty is evidence of negligence); *Lyon v. Morphew*, 424 Mass. 828 (1997).
*Lyon v. Morphew*, 424 Mass. 828 (1997).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the rule that a violation of a statutory duty is evidence of negligence. In Lyon v. Morphew, the court does mention that duties can be created by statute and cites other cases (such as St. Germaine and Rae) for that point, but it does not discuss or apply the specific Bennett principle that violation of a statute is evidence of negligence. Instead, Lyon focuses on whether any statutory or common-law duty existed at all and concludes it did not. It therefore does not provide authority for the proposition cited.
*Lyon v. Morphew*, 424 Mass. 828 (1997).relevant_excerpt: "In addition, a duty may be created by statute. See St. Germaine v. Pendergast, 411 Mass. 615, 619 (1992) (duty to comply with State building code); Rae v. Air-Speed, Inc., 386 Mass. 187, 193 (1982) (G. L. c. 152, §§ 66, 67, duty to provide workers’ compensation insurance). Absent a common law or statutory duty, an employee may not be held individually liable to a third person."

*Jex v. Jex*, 432 Mass. 533 (2000).proposition: See *Jex v. Jex*, 432 Mass. 533 (2000); *Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 376 Mass. 101 (1978).
*Jex v. Jex*, 432 Mass. 533 (2000).support_reasoning: The proposition given is just a bare cross-citation: 'See Jex v. Jex ...; Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth. ...' with no articulated legal principle. Without knowing the specific legal rule the author is invoking, it is impossible to say that Jex clearly supports it. The Jex opinion concerns Article 48 initiative-petition exclusions (powers of courts, appropriations, reversal of judicial decisions, relatedness, etc.), and nothing in the provided text indicates what combined proposition with Jesionek it is supposed to support.
*Jex v. Jex*, 432 Mass. 533 (2000).relevant_excerpt: We have construed the powers of courts exclusion as prohibiting petitions whose main purpose is to affect the powers of courts. A petition whose main purpose is otherwise, though it may affect the work of the courts, is permissible. See Commonwealth v. Yee, supra at 537-538... Contrast Commonwealth v. Sacco, 255 Mass. 369, 410-411 (1926) (law empowering Superior Court to grant new trials at any time before sentencing was law relating to powers of courts).

*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.proposition: See *Jex v. Jex*, 432 Mass. 533 (2000); *Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 376 Mass. 101 (1978).
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.support_reasoning: The ‘proposition’ provided is only a cross-reference string—“See Jex v. Jex (2000); Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth. (1978)”—and does not state any concrete legal principle to evaluate. Jesionek clearly concerns foreseeability and proximate cause where a landowner negligently leaves a dangerous instrumentality (a forklift) unsecured, but without knowing the specific principle for which Jex and Jesionek are being cited together, it is impossible to say that this opinion supports that unidentified proposition. The case does support a general rule about foreseeable misuse by third parties not breaking causation, but whether that matches the unstated proposition is unclear.
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen.…’ … Since the vehicle involved in this case was not in fact stolen, the general rule concerning the conduct of third parties … control[s] this action.… [A] jury could have found that the plaintiff’s injury was caused by a negligent act for which the authority was responsible.”

*Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.*.raw_text: *Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.*, 388 Mass. 342, 355 (1983)
*Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.*.proposition: See *Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.*, 388 Mass. 342, 355 (1983) (plaintiff’s due care presumed unless shown otherwise); *Asiala v. Fitchburg*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 13 (1987).
*Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.*.case_name: Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.
*Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.*.support_reasoning: The cited portion of Correia discusses comparative negligence and strict products liability/warranty, and clarifies when a plaintiff’s own unreasonable use of a known defective and dangerous product will bar recovery because that conduct is deemed the proximate cause. It does not state or imply any presumption that a plaintiff acted with due care; rather, it focuses on when plaintiff conduct defeats recovery. Thus, Correia does not support the proposition that a plaintiff’s due care is presumed unless shown otherwise.
*Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.*.relevant_excerpt: “Given this focus, the only duty imposed on the user is to act reasonably with respect to a product which he knows to be defective and dangerous. When a user unreasonably proceeds to use a product which he knows to be defective and dangerous, he violates that duty and relinquishes the protection of the law. It is only then that it is appropriate to account for his conduct in determining liability. Since he has voluntarily relinquished the law’s protection, it is further appropriate that he be barred from recovery. … In such circumstances, the user’s conduct alone is the proximate cause of his injuries, as a matter of law, and recovery is appropriately denied.”

*Asiala v. Fitchburg*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: See *Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.*, 388 Mass. 342, 355 (1983) (plaintiff’s due care presumed unless shown otherwise); *Asiala v. Fitchburg*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 13 (1987).
*Asiala v. Fitchburg*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a presumption that a plaintiff exercised due care unless shown otherwise, referencing Correia. Asiala is a nuisance/sovereign-immunity/statute-of-limitations case about whether the Massachusetts Tort Claims Act applies to municipal private nuisance claims; it does not discuss negligence concepts like due care, contributory or comparative negligence, or any presumption of the plaintiff’s due care. Therefore, Asiala does not support the stated proposition and is being cited inaccurately for that point.
*Asiala v. Fitchburg*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: We agree with the plaintiff that her amended complaint alleged that the defendant created and maintained a private nuisance. The essence of a private nuisance action is some interference with the use and enjoyment of property. … We conclude, in view of the history and nature of private nuisance actions, and from an examination of G. L. c. 258, that it was not the intention of the Legislature to include such actions in the Act.
